Fields.DialogueText: That's everything. Repairs complete, supplies loaded, and all personnel accounted for. Time to get back to sea for our next patrol.
Captain, wait!
Argonaut, we're casting off our mooring lines. Hurry up to the bridge.
But my entrance! You have to announce me!
Argonaut, I need you up here in the bridge. Now.
Pretty please?

Fields.MenuText: Act like a warship, not a Hollywood starlet.
"Argonaut to the bridge!" How's that?
"Ladies and gentlemen, children of all ages, she's fresh from a refit and ready to fight. She's the most glamorous Belle in the fleet... AR-GO-NAUUUUT!"

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph! Then move over a step, darling. I'm climbing this ladder in heels, you know.
Functional, but lacking in style. You have a lot to learn, Captain.
Oh! How thrilling! Thank you so very much, my lovely Captain! HERE I COME!
It's little old me, your humble Belle. Oh, thank you, thank you! Autographs? Oh, darling, you flatter me... but does anybody have a pen?
We're the only two souls in the bridge, and I don't need your autograph, Argonaut.
I wasn't talking to you, silly goose. I was talking to them.
What?
That little crowd of adoring fans over yonder, of course! Try your binoculars off the starboard beam and you'll see them.
Uh-oh. Those aren't fans...
Morganas? What a disappointment. Perhaps I should have planned our red carpet event to make sure the riffraff was excluded.
Let's roll up our sleeves and give them a proper bouncing out of our port, Argonaut.
With pleasure, darling!
@BATTLE
But...
Bridge. Now.
Hit your marks, Captain! Just because we are the stars of the show, it doesn't mean that we can be sloppy. The entire cast is counting on us!
By "cast," I presume you mean "crew."
Yes, whatever, darling. We have a big day ahead of us, and we need to be off-book.

Fields.MenuText: What book are you talking about?
Off-book... You mean like a script?
This is NOT a movie. We're NOT actors. My uniform is NOT a costume.

Fields.DialogueText: Not a book! I mean the script, darling!
Yes, exactly!
And all the same, we must learn our parts, my dear!
It's a real war out there, Argonaut. I don't want you losing sight of that.
War is like a Hollywood feature – we have to play our part to perfection, Captain...
... and I'd appreciate it if you didn't make me look bad.
Oh, brother...
*ALARM*
What?! It's not time to start the show yet!
Get to your station, Argonaut. It's showtime.
But I still need ten more minutes in make-up!
Now!
@BATTLE
I looked positively stunning out there, didn't I? A veritable goddess, guns blazing with panache and power!
Damage reports, please.
Smiting our enemies with flair...
Damage reports. I'm waiting.
Oh! And my hair still looks fabulous, if I may say so myself.

Fields.MenuText: We have procedures aboard this submarine, Argonaut. After combat action, I need to see those damage reports.
Yes, yes. You were wonderful. Can I please get those damage reports, now?
Now that you mention it, your hair DOES look amazing! How do you keep yourself so composed under fire?

Fields.DialogueText: How... pedestrian of you. Yes, yes, the Fleet's most glamorous Belle will stoop to fetching your precious paperwork, darling.
I feel inadequately flattered, but I'm glad to see you trying. Yes, I'll get those reports to you right away.
Anything can go wrong on the set, my dear, but a professional sees it through with poise.
Your reports are coming soon, but I'll say right now that our beautiful guns stole the show that time.
Glad to hear the guns chattering for once and not just your big-
My big what?
Um...
My mouth?
Forget I said anything.
How can I forget a comment like that when-
*ALARM*
Oh! More adoring fans coming this way! Places, everyone!
@BATTLE
We have a long list of priority items, Miss Argonaut...
And I say that list needs to be fixed! Am I not the glamorous starlet here? My order goes to the top!
But...
The TOP!
What in the hell is going on here?
Captain, darling, please explain to your assistant that my needs are important.
What needs are we talking about?
A large order of paint, Captain, to-
Paint? I distinctly said makeup, Officer Barchet!

Fields.MenuText: We don't have time for makeup, Argonaut.
We can't have our ship coming apart because of rust, Mr. Barchet. Please add paint to the order.
Hurry, Mr. Barchet! If our star needs makeup, we get her makeup!

Fields.DialogueText: Have you any idea what salt water does to my complexion?
Makeup, darling. And thank you.
I told you, my dear!
Thank you for... resolving that issue, Captain. Attending to trifles personally tends to make me perspire.
Belles sweat?
"Perspire" is more elegant, my dear. Sweat is so... unbecoming of a Hollywood star like yours truly, don't you agree?
*ALARM*
I don't think the Morganas care either way, Argonaut. Battle stations!
I know what to do! Honestly, I require far less direction than you feel it necessary to give, Captain.
@BATTLE
I'll take care of it, Miss Argonaut, if it will keep you quiet.
That will be all for now, darling.
I'll take care of it, Miss Argonaut.
I'll take care of it, Miss Argonaut.
Oh, poo. It seems that my pencil is broken. Would you happen to have a spare for your favorite Belle?
A pencil? Sure. Here you go.
Thank you ever so much, my lovely.
I'm used to hearing more extravagant demands from you. A pencil seems far too easy.
Easy? Why, it's positively critical! How else will I make adjustments to your copy of the script I've been working on?
My script?
Hold out your hands, darling. There you are! Now you can learn your new lines.
New lines?! This must be over a hundred pages! We have standard operating procedures, Argonaut. Why do I need a script?
To rehearse, silly goose! Now, scene four, from the top.
Enter, stage left, the beautiful young heroine. That's me, of course.
"Goodness! What unholy gift will these waters foist upon us this day?"
Ahem.
I said, "What unholy gift will these waters foist upon us this day?" That's your cue, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not doing this, Argonaut.
"Even a beautiful and wise Belle, such as yourself, can only guess at such things!"
I think "What unholy gift MIGHT these waters foist" would sound more dramatic, don't you?

Fields.DialogueText: How disappointing...
Oh! I rather like your inflection on that line, Captain. Still... it needs something more...
Quite the ear for melodrama, Captain! I'll make that change right now.
Our heroine continues... "And whatever should come, we must prevail!"
Annnnnnd... scene.
Ah, well. A work in progress, my love. I'll make some revisions and get you a new copy as soon as I can.
Finish your gunnery and torpedo practice, first.
Please, please, please find me an assistant for such things, Captain. Just thinking about chores makes my head hurt.
And that might give me wrinkles!
*ALARM*
Let's get going, Argonaut.
Wrinkles, Captain! Wrinkles!
@BATTLE
Barchet, what in the hell is wrong with our rudder?
Captain?
We keep fishtailing side to side. Can't you feel it? I had to step over three seasick sailors just to get here from my cabin.
I'm feeling a bit queasy myself, now that you mention it.
Did Argonaut say anything about problems with the rudder? When I order a course, I expect the helm to steer it.
Miss Argonaut wanted to-
Did I hear somebody calling my name? I only have a moment to spare, but I'll do anything for my fans.

Fields.MenuText: We're swerving left and right, and our crew is getting seasick.
Is our rudder coming loose?
Did you notice that we're not driving a straight course?

Fields.DialogueText: Those poor people! I must have gotten carried away with my little experiment.
My rudder is in perfect working order, Captain. No need for anybody to leer at it!
I was a bit distracted, Captain.
I was in the bridge, you see, trying to figure out whether my port side or my starboard side looked better in the natural light.
Both sides are amazing, but certainly one of them must be MORE amazing than the other.
We wouldn't want other ships to see our bad side, would we?
Captain, you might want to speak to makeup. Your face is turning red.
When I order a course, we drive it. I want us steady on that course. Steady. Not a zigzag.
And then, darling, could you imagine if a camera crew were to show up? Ha!
An order.
Well! Not everyone has a head for show business, I see.
@BATTLE
Experiment?
*ALARM*
These last few combat engagements have been a great shakedown for the new equipment - propellers and all. HQ's happy with our combat efficiency.
Oh, if you say so.
Was it really so bad, Argonaut?
A pity we have to use the guns so much.
I couldn't agree more. We should all wish for a day when we won't need to fire them again.
Exactly! Because no matter how much I clean them, they'll never look quite so new and fresh as they first did. Yes, truly, war is hell.

Fields.MenuText: That... wasn't really my point.
It doesn't matter how the guns look. It matters how they shoot.
Did YOU actually clean the guns?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe you should try keeping the guns clean for yourself, and you'll understand just how terrible it is.
When a ship is this beautiful, her looks always matter, my dear.
Me? Cleaning? Not personally, no... but I supervised the cleaning. Exhausting!
Feel free to inspect for yourself, Captain. Our guns may not shine quite like when they were first installed, but they're still ready for a close-up.
I'm sure they're spotless, but I'll have a look to show my appreciation for the hard work.
Here, take this white glove if you'd like to use it for your inspection.
Thanks, Argonaut. I'd-
*ALARM*
No! No! Not now!
General quarters, Argonaut. Get the gun crews here on the double, ready to fire.
We just cleaned them! NO!
Oh... Oh, dear... I... Uhhhh...
Argonaut?
Get me a medic over here! Argonaut just fainted!
Nonsense, Captain. I'm fine. See? I'm on my feet again.
Just a bit of drama to express myself. Was I convincing?
I'm convinced about something, all right...
@BATTLE
Steady on ordered depth, Captain. The ship is submerged.
Very well, Mr. Barchet. Keep a sharp eye on that periscope while I look at our charts.
Aye aye, Captain.
Captain, I don't mean to intrude – but I have a question.
What's that, Miss Argonaut?
How much longer until we surface again?

Fields.MenuText: At this speed, we've got plenty of time on our batteries.
That depends. How long can you hold your breath?
We just finished our dive. Why are you so impatient?

Fields.DialogueText: A shame. A shame we deny the world a look at my beautiful hull for so long at a time.
Ha! When did you become a comedian? If your jokes were any good, you could be my opening act.
How can anybody SEE us down here?
Come on, Argonaut, who are you trying to impress out here? I'm sure the Morganas will be rightly awed by a torpedo up their noses.
Oh, yes, I'm sure they will, Captain. In fact, I believe I can sense something...
*ALARM*
Right on cue!
Make all tubes ready. Get the outer doors open, Argonaut.
I know my lines, Captain!
@BATTLE
Mind if I come in, Argonaut? I brought you some coffee.
How thoughtful! Yes, do come in. My dressing room door is unlocked.
On a warship, we call them "cabins" or "staterooms" – not dressing rooms.
Yes, yes. Just hand me that cup.
Is something the matter? You've got lines all over your face like Bela Lugosi.
Just a bit concerned about you. Are you all right, Argonaut? It seems like you're taking these battles a little hard.
Oh, no, nothing is wrong, my sweet Captain. I am just a little preoccupied.

Fields.MenuText: If something's bothering you, I need to hear about it. Your well-being is one of my responsibilities.
Argonaut, you know you can tell me anything, right? I can't help unless you're honest with me.
If you say so. What say you get back out there and show the fleet what you can do?

Fields.DialogueText: A tad impersonal, Captain. I may be a little... off, but it's nothing to worry about.
Tugging at my heartstrings, Captain? You deliver that line with conviction! I'll be fine, I promise.
Of course, Captain. I'll aim to impress. We can't disappoint the fans!
*ALARM*
My troubles will have to wait.
Your troubles...
Forgotten for the moment, and no time for makeup. The show must go on!
@BATTLE
You're really pulling your weight out there, Argonaut!
My ears appreciate your kind words, Captain.
I noticed a decrease in the number of complaints from the chief electrician, too.
The shipyard gave my wiring the once-over, to good effect.
It must have been a magical time for them, now that I think about it.

Fields.MenuText: Working on your wiring was magical?
Giving you the once-over was magical?
You graced their dirty shipyard with your unparalleled Hollywood glamour. "Magical" can hardly begin to cover it!

Fields.DialogueText: Bah! I'll admit, wiring isn't my best feature.
A creature of beauty, such as my humble self, brings magic to all who gaze upon her.
Ah! You touch my heart in all the right places, darling. We share an understanding, don't we?
Thanks to their hard work, I should suffer fewer electrical problems now.
We live or die by our batteries and electrical systems, Argonaut. Keep our breakers dry.
I'll do my best. Nobody wants a fire aboard a submarine.
Exactly.
What if my wardrobe were to burn up? Can you imagine the horror of it all?
I suddenly feel the urge to attend to matters elsewhere.
Exit, stage left... and enter the villains of our piece. Parting is such sweet sorrow, darling!
Is she ever going to take this seriously?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Is Mr. Barchet around? We've got a big problem.
We must be worried about the same thing. I've had dreadful issues with our dehumidifiers failing. My wardrobe has taken on a horrid, musty smell!
I've actually got something more important on my mind, Argonaut.
More important than my clothes!? You must be teasing me, darling.
HQ sent us a flash message about Morganas breaking through our minefields. The numbers getting past our line are too damn high.
So, where is Barchet?
Oh, I wouldn't worry about him. Always so dreadfully busy with the crew, dear. Why not just talk to me?
Because the last time I talked about minefields you pretended to fall asleep. You even made snoring noises until I left!
And my performance becomes more convincing each time, wouldn't you agree? Stagecraft!

Fields.MenuText: I need to talk to somebody that cares about the mission.
This isn't a movie, Argonaut. We're in a war, remember?
Pretending to be asleep or dead might fool the Morganas in the right situation... but this isn't the time for that.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh.
And when they make a movie about the war, I'll be magnificent in a starring role!
I'll save it for just the right moment, darling.
But this minefield business. Try me! I can be a good listener, and I'm sure I have good thoughts on the subject.
All right, I suppose I can give it a try. What do you make of the minefield penetrations? Any thoughts on how to slow the Morganas down?
Argonaut?
Zzzzz...
Argonaut! Oh, for crying out loud.
*ALARM*
Hm? You were saying? Oh, Captain, I think that's the alarm. We can talk about minefields later, perhaps.
Get your guns ready. We'll talk later... or maybe we won't.
@BATTLE
We need answers, and fast! These Morganas keep finding ways through our minefields.
You... you slammed your hand on the desk so forcefully, Captain...
Oh. Sorry. Did that hurt you?
It's just a desk, silly goose. I can feel combat damage to the ship, but a desk is just a desk.
Then please explain why you're looking at me like that. Your eyes are huge and you haven't blinked.
Your frustration! Your passion! Quite a powerful performance, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Really? You think so? Are you saying that maybe... "a star is born"?
I'm not acting, Argonaut!
Argonaut, we're in a war. Not a movie. We're on a submarine, not a movie set. I'm actually frustrated... for real.

Fields.DialogueText: Mmm... maybe so! You can certainly express your emotions.
Speak for yourself, but I think you might have what it takes! Do you have an agent?
Riiiiight...
That was exhilarating, Captain. I thoroughly enjoyed our little conversation. Time for me to go!
But we haven't come up with any answers about the minefields!
What?
*ALARM*
Ta-ta! To be continued, my dear!
This isn't over!
Oh! You gave me chills that time! You really know how to make a cliffhanger, Captain!
@BATTLE
Knock it off!
Suit yourself...
And stop winking at me.
You've been doing your acting exercises, haven't you? Excellent work, but don't forget to breathe, Captain!
Miss Argonaut...
Is something the matter, Mr. Barchet?
I don't think the captain is in a playful mood.
Nonsense, darling. I believe our good captain is pausing for dramatic effect.
If I look short of breath, it's only because I just got ridden like HQ's pony. Command is still furious about the gaps in our minefield defense.
The minefield story again? I admire your dedication, but that scene gets a bit tiresome.
Miss Argonaut... please don't make things any worse.
I'd love to see you do something fresh.

Fields.MenuText: If you aren't going to help, then go away. The rest of us have a war to fight.
Please focus on the issue, Argonaut.
MINEFIELD! MINEFIELD! MINEFIELD!

Fields.DialogueText: Are you cutting me from the scene!?
Yes, Captain.
OH! Bravo, Captain! I am moved by your performance!
You will find me dedicated to the task. Please let me know what I can do to help.
I want to get an operational analysis of our minefields. We need to use our stealth and observe how the Morganas defeat our mines.
Um... It might be important to mention that-
Sneeze! Erm, I meant, "A-chooo!" Yes, A-CHOOO, I say!
What?
Yes, that's it. Cough! I say, cough! Cough! COUGH!
*ALARM*
Damn! Another Morgana penetration? It's as though our mines don't even exist!
@BATTLE
Thank you for your candor, Mr. Barchet. I understand the problem with the minefield now.
Of course. And... I'd have said something to you sooner, but-
No apologies necessary. Argonaut put you in a difficult situation.
If that's all, Captain...
Yes. Dismissed. Send her in, please.
That's my cue!
Hmm... Captain, is your dressing room larger than mine?
It's not a dressing room. It's your commanding officer's stateroom – and you've been called in here for a reason!
Your eyes! Captain, darling, you look as though you could spit fire at this moment.
I could, now that Mr. Barchet told me what you did to our minelayers in the shipyard.
Oh... About that...
Explain to me, Miss Argonaut, why you tricked the refit engineers into removing our minelayers!
I didn't like them.

Fields.MenuText: They weren't glamorous enough for you?
You didn't want to get your hands dirty doing hard work laying mines?
You didn't think defending the fleet from Morgana attacks was important?

Fields.DialogueText: Didn't you notice the unsightly bulges? Minelayers are hardly in fashion this year.
It was murder on my nails, Captain. Do you know how hard it is to get a decent manicure on a warship?
Oh, the fleet can handle Morganas without a few silly mines.
I don't have time for a Belle that refuses her mission. Or a Belle that sweet-talks refit engineers into removing vital equipment.
Get out.
You heard me. I need some time to compose my report to HQ. Close the door on your way out.
Yes, Captain.
*ALARM*
Brilliant. She'll be pouting for the whole fight.
@BATTLE
Our beauty enters, from stage left...
I'd rather you knocked before you walked into my stateroom, Argonaut.
Precisely why I did you the courtesy of reading my stage directions. I had no intention of taking you by surprise, Captain.
But that's exactly what you did. Surprise me.
I won't be coy today, my dear. I know what I did was wrong.
Getting rid of our minelaying equipment was definitely wrong, Argonaut.
And I'm here to... to apologize. Can a Belle find forgiveness from such a gallant Captain?

Fields.MenuText: It will take more than batting your eyelashes to fix the problem.
Saying "sorry" doesn't fix the holes in our minefields. Apologies won't stop them from getting through.
I understand. I'm glad you accept responsibility for your actions.

Fields.DialogueText: I respectfully disagree, Captain. That's exactly what I intend to do.
I have a plan for that, Captain.
Yes, Captain. And that's not all...
I'll use my charms to convince the engineers to... reinstall my minelaying equipment.
That's a major shipyard job, Argonaut. And HQ is already upset with us for removing them in the first place.
But I must make things right! I caused the problem, and I will fix it.
My requests for a spot in the shipyard were all denied. If you think you can do better...
Follow me to the radio room, and I'll show you what happens when I get a microphone in my hand!
I hope you're right.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
The installation is already finished? We hardly finished mooring!
Argonaut worked her magic, Captain. Somehow she charmed the shipyard workers and convinced them to install our new minelayers immediately.
It was a thing of beauty, really.
"A thing of beauty," you say? That MUST be my cue. Hello, Captain.
Is it true? We've got our minelayers back?
Glamorous VIPs, such as yours truly, belong on the top of the list, my darlings.
A brief moment with me was all the shipyard workers needed to see the truth of that.

Fields.MenuText: Glad to see your charms do some good, for once.
Another shipyard bamboozled by Argonaut. I hope we don't regret this.
Just remember that batting your eyelashes won't fool me.

Fields.DialogueText: "For once?" Hmph... but a true star lets such things roll off her back.
We won't!
Oh? Are you so certain of that?
The important thing is that our minelayers are back. I want this submarine underway and on task as soon as possible.
I'll start our checklists, Captain. We should be at sea in moments.
Are you proud of me, darling?
This isn't the time, Argonaut. We need to do our jobs and get that minefield in order.
I promise the fleet's premier submarine will perform with style and grace!
@BATTLE
Keep up the good work, Mr. Barchet. We should be able to plug the gaps in the minefield before long.
Aye-aye, Captain. Nothing will get past us.
But, Captain, it's so boring out there! Driving these lines, back and forth just to drop a mine here and there. I feel like...
Like a farmer. Planting dreary little rows of crops.

Fields.MenuText: Explosives, Argonaut. Not seeds. Lose sight of that, and we might have a terrible accident.
Imagine it as practicing for a role as a farmer. Just think how convincing you'd be in a movie with a farm!
What's wrong with being a farmer?

Fields.DialogueText: Good grief! I may be prone to imagination, but I'm not about to strike one with a shovel!
Oh! I'd be just like Judy Garland on that farm in Kansas... though I don't think she did any manual labor in The Wizard of Oz, did she?
Nothing, if you like having dirty hands and a sunburn.
Remember how we got into this mess?
And I suppose that only hard work will get us out of it. Back to my "farming," then.
Wear a bonnet if that helps get you into character.
Are you mocking me?
Not a terrible idea, though. I'll send an assistant to the costume department and see if-
Warship, Argonaut. Warship. No costume department.
Right.
Oh, what I wouldn't give for a distraction from this drudgery, Captain.
*ALARM*
That is NOT your cue, Morganas!
@BATTLE
What's wrong now? That look on your face could curdle milk.
Hardly befitting a starlet, I know! My circumstances, however, permit me no other options, darling.
Oh, do tell.
Really? I would, if only there were more to tell.
I don't see the problem, then.
And that's precisely the problem. I have nothing to tell! Boredom!
Get over it. You made this bed. You're going to lie in it until we can get the defenses shored up.
This is so unfair! You subject me to more pedestrian tasking than any other submarine!
The thing is... you're actually very good at it.
But, Captain, darling! I'm so tired of this!

Fields.MenuText: Too bad. You don't get shiny new toys and then sit at home with them.
You are going to learn some responsibility if it kills all of us.
Just get out there. I'm getting annoyed listening to you complain.

Fields.DialogueText: But that's the point of having them all shiny! Why else would they look so nice?
I refuse to take any responsibility for my actions if that responsibility is so boring.
Captain, you are so mean to me! Why do you treat me so, my dear?
Get back out there and lay those mines, Argonaut. I'm not in the mood.
*ALARM*
Oh, sweet diversion! It looks like minelaying will have to wait!
@BATTLE
Mr. Barchet! Why did it take so long for us to submerge the sub? I gave that order almost an hour ago.
We had some difficulty getting below.
A stuck valve? Problem with the ballast tanks? What was the delay?
It was Argonaut. She's become quite difficult. When I ordered her to dive the boat, she pretended not to hear me for almost half an hour.
Unprofessional. A surly warship doesn't seem like a safe place to be.
She complains about boredom incessantly. If we can't find her something to do, we might end up dealing with tantrums.
I don't think tantrums are something I want from a submarine either. Very well, I'll look into it.
Officers! Discussing anything fun? Need your beloved Argonaut for anything, my darlings?

Fields.MenuText: Actually, yes. Would you mind giving me some advice on my acting talents?
We always need you, Argonaut. For what, I'm not sure yet.
Patrols, at the moment, but I'm sure we'll come up with something else in due time.

Fields.DialogueText: Always, my darling! I will shape you into the perfect lead or my name isn't Argonaut!
My presence alone could launch a thousand ships. Or this ship a thousand times.
Oh, boo! Please come up with something else? I'm ever so bored with patrols.
Was that the same Argonaut?
Strange...
*ALARM*
Worry about that later! The proximity alarms are going off.
@BATTLE
Listen. Can you hear that?
I don't hear anything, Captain.
Exactly, Mr. Barchet. A proper submarine on patrol should be as quiet as-
*CRASH*
DAMN!
I almost broke a NAIL!
This is a DISASTER!
As quiet as a what, Captain?
Sigh. As quiet as a silent film, Mr. Barchet...
I don't think Miss Argonaut would ever be part of a silent film, Captain.
Did somebody say "film"? Oh, never mind that. We have a crisis, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: Did our engines explode?
Did we smash into a rock?
Are we under attack?

Fields.DialogueText: No such luck, Captain. Our situation is direr than that!
Perish the thought, darling!
Thankfully, no! But we do have an urgent problem!
Our passageways are far too small to fit suitable lighting. How can we ever shoot a proper scene?
Shoot a scene? For the umpteenth time, Argonaut, this is a warship! We're not a Hollywood set.
What will future generations think of us if they have nothing but grainy footage of our adventures?
We're not filming anything!
And why not?
Because... because...
I'm waiting, my dear. Deliver your line.
Argonaut, I never thought I'd say this, but you just gave me an idea.
I am quite the muse, so the directors say...
Maybe we could-
*ALARM*
Oh! Another interruption?! These Morganas never wait for their cue!
@BATTLE
That's the last of them, darling. Every dreary mine in its proper place. Are you happy?
My happiness doesn't matter. That mission serves the fleet, Argonaut.
If I take any pleasure from this situation at all, it's that my stowage is finally empty. It feels more spacious now, like a proper luxury vessel.
Don't get used to it. We'll pick up more mines with our next resupply. Until then, Argonaut, I've got a new deal for you.
Oh? A new role to play? Tell me more, my lovely Captain.
I was thinking about a way to augment our defenses.
Boring, my dear.
Hear me out, Argonaut. You may find yourself uniquely suited for this task.
Oh?
Then again, I shouldn't be surprised. Not everybody can play the part of the leading lady. What did you have in mind?
HQ knew the Morganas were penetrating the minefields, but they never had solid reconnaissance to show how they accomplished it...

Fields.MenuText: Maybe your expertise with film could come in handy.
We could shoot reconnaissance footage of the Morganas trying to break through.
Ever wanted to direct your own movie?

Fields.DialogueText: You have only to ask, darling! Tell me more.
How is that anything like a film?
Yes! What kind of movie did you have in mind?
Think of it like a spy movie, starring the Morganas.
Ugh. You have terrible taste in talent, my dear. Still, I think I understand what you have in mind.
Let me call my agent, and-
You can't be serious, Argonaut. Do you really have an agent?!
No...
But one must keep up appearances, Captain. I have my fans to think about!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Put a pin in that. We're under attack.
Are you all right, Mr. Barchet? You have a white-knuckle grip on the periscope handles.
I'm sweating bullets, and you should be, too! We're taking the sub dangerously close to our own minefield.
A necessary hazard for us to get close enough for reconnaissance.
Don't lose your nerve. Keep us on a precise course, and we'll swim around the mines.
Mines don't know friend from foe, Captain. A single mistake costs us everything.
Just drive carefully, and don't rip those periscope handles off.
I sense some tension on the set today. Have no fear! Your star is here!
Hardly reassuring...
AHEM!
Tell me, Argonaut...

Fields.MenuText: Did you help the navigator to verify the location of our minefields?
Can you help Mr. Barchet settle down?
Could you survive hitting one of our own mines?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes... and it was tedious work, my dear. Almost as tedious as laying those mines in the first place.
Remind him that even the most glamorous Hollywood stars can experience anxiety with close-ups... but we must perform!
Even a star submarine such as myself would have trouble surviving such a thing. Let's not find out for ourselves, all right?
Everybody, there's no other way. We've got to maneuver as close as we can to observe the Morganas breaking through the minefields.
And if we need to evade quickly?
Avoid panicking. If we trip over a mine trying to evade, we do the Morganas' work for them...
Here comes one now.
I hope we know what we're doing.
Stop sweating, darling! The cameras are about to start rolling!
@BATTLE
That's what I thought.
Sometimes we fight, sometimes we let them go. I don't understand this screenplay, darling.
For the last time, Argonaut!
This.
Is.
NOT.
A Hollywood movie!
You deliver your lines with such force, Captain, but look around! I must disagree. We have a camera attached to my periscope, do we not?
We are here to observe the Morganas...

Fields.MenuText: ... to obtain vital intelligence on where they cross our minefields.
... to catch Morganas before they break through and terrorize the fleet.
Never mind. Forget what I said. Yes, we're shooting a movie, and the Morganas are the villains. We need some dramatic footage up close.

Fields.DialogueText: So you say... but perhaps you're just playing your character to the hilt. "Aye-aye, Captain."
Are you so blind to the dramatic possibilities? This would make a wonderful war movie! Follow my lead, and I'll make you a star like me!
I KNEW IT! And you couldn't have a better Belle for such a mission!
Here come big ones. Oh, how unsightly! In Hollywood, we'd say that they have faces for radio.
Make all torpedo tubes ready. If they make it through the mines, we mark their path and then we take them down.
Oh, how absolutely wretched they look, darling.
Maybe we shouldn't put those Morganas in our movie. Viewers would vomit into their popcorn at the sight of them!
Hush up and keep that camera rolling, Argonaut.
Oh... they're heading right for one of our mines! We've got them.
We're close enough to feel the pressure wave when it goes off, so brace for impact.
Any second now...
Any... second...
They're through... The only way they could do that is...
Damn! Did I forget to put a mine there?
Looks like we found a gap.
And so did they. I don't normally improvise, Captain, but we need to attack now before the secret can be shared.
Good instincts. I like your sense of timing, Argonaut!
I'm actually quite famous for my timing, darling.
@BATTLE
We've plotted the precise location of that gap, Captain.
Good work, Mr. Barchet. Once we clear this area of Morganas, we'll have to lay more mines here.
Ugh! Minelaying? Again!? Honestly, my darlings, can't we find something more exciting to do?

Fields.MenuText: It's your job, Argonaut. Quit griping.
It's our job, Argonaut. Take some pride in it.
Think of it as reprising a starring role. We couldn't replace you with another Belle, could we?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm... I'm not being difficult! My agent would never forgive me if I developed a reputation for being difficult to work with, darling.
I take pride in all of my work, my dear. That doesn't mean I have to like it.
Ha! When you put it that way... of course you can't! My shoes are too big for just any old Belle to fill!
Then it's settled. Time to follow this next pack of Morganas. If they find a way through our minefield, we've found the next gap.
Aye-aye, Captain.
And then we'll blast them full of holes, right?
That's right.
I told you I learn my lines quickly!
No explosions yet, and they're getting closer.
Get your guns and torpedoes ready, Argonaut. I think we have a scene to shoot.
Places, everyone!
@BATTLE
The star makes her entrance into the Captain's dressing room from stage left...
Oops! I meant to say "stateroom," my dear.
It's all right. Come on in, Argonaut.
Our task is finally complete. We've laid new mines in every gap that the Morganas were exploiting to cross our defenses.
I'm sure HQ will be happy we've patched up the minefields. That remedies a major fleet vulnerability.
I must ask, darling, is there more to say? I pride myself on reading facial expressions, but you have me at a loss.
Oh, just a few things to say about your recent performance.
Notes? For me!? I assure you, I strive to keep my work as professional as possible. What could it possibly be?
Relax.

Fields.MenuText: You handled that stressful mission with style. It impressed me.
You proved that you're more than just a Hollywood starlet.
You exceeded my expectations, Argonaut. When the mission called, you answered.

Fields.DialogueText: Is that all? Ha! You're quite welcome, darling.
Few Belles could handle the strain of being a starlet AND a deadly warship, Captain.
You command the fleet's premier submarine, Captain. You should expect the best!
And now I have a question for you, Captain.
Shoot.
Does the fleet have Academy Awards?
Ha! If there was an Academy Award for Best Submarine, I can't think of any other Belle I'd nominate.
Oh! Really? REALLY!?
I didn't prepare a speech! So many people to thank!
First, I'd like to thank Mr. Barchet for earnest determination under fire. I'd also like to thank HQ for believing in a humble Belle like me.
Humble?
Sssh! Not now, my dear. I'm not finished yet.
And I'd also like to thank my noble captain – the one who pushed me to work harder than ever and who put their heart into every scene.
I've come to see my captain not only as a fine officer, but as someone I am proud to consider my friend.
Bravo, Argonaut!
And... scene!
@BATTLE
